DEVIATION.Definition: to do something that is different from the usual or common way of behaving

‍AVOIDING.Definition: staying away from someone or something

‍PAT ON THE BACK.Definition: praise, e.g. he gave himself a pat on the back for his achievements

‍DISHEARTENED.Definition: having lost confidence, hope, and energy

‍HACKS.Definition: shortcuts that avoid you doing what others do

‍SQUEEZE.Definition: to force someone or something into a small space or a short period of time

‍MOTIVATE.Definition: to make someone want to do something well

‍CHORE.Definition: a job or piece of work that is often boring or unpleasant but needs to be done regularly

‍OVER AND ABOVE.Definition: above or higher than something else, sometimes so that one thing covers the other

‍SMALL-TALK.Definition: conversation about things that are not important, often between people who do not know each other well

‍PACE.Definition: the speed at which someone or something moves, or with which something happens or changes

‍ENGAGE.Definition: to become involved, or have contact, with someone or something

‍TACTICS.Definition: a planned way of doing something

‍ZERO-SUM.Definition: used to refer to a situation in which any win by one person always means a loss to another person involved

‍ENDLESSLY.Definition: in a way that is endless (= never finishing, or seeming never to finish)

‍CORE.Definition: the basic and most important part of something

‍MIRACULOUSLY.Definition: in a way that is very surprising or difficult to believe

‍MINIMISE.Definition: to reduce something to the least possible level or amount

‍FRAMING.Definition: to express something choosing your words carefully

‍TEDIOUS.Definition: boring Relish: to like or enjoy something

‍ELUSIVE.Definition: difficult to describe, find, achieve, or remember

‍AS USEFUL AS BEING HIT IN THE FACE WITH.Definition: used to indicate that something isn't useful at all

‍PATRONISE.Definition: to speak to or behave towards someone as if they are stupid or not important

‍LITERATE.Definition: having a good education or showing it in your writing‍

NOD.Definition: to move your head down and then up, sometimes several times, especially to show agreement, approval, or greeting, or to show something by doing this

‍SCHOLARSHIP.Definition: an amount of money given by a school, college, university, or other organization to pay for the studies of a person

‍MOUSTACHE.Definition: hair that a man grows above his upper lip

‍PRESTIGIOUS.Definition: respect and admiration given to someone or something, usually because of a reputation for high quality, success, or social influence

‍ORATORS.Definition: someone who is good at public speaking

‍HESITATE.Definition: to pause before you do or say something, often because you are uncertain or nervous about it

‍COMES ACROSS.Definition: to behave in a way that makes people believe that you have a particular characteristic

‍PROXY.Definition: a situation, process, or activity to which another situation, etc. is compared, especially in order to calculate how successful or unsuccessful it is

‍LINGUISTIC.Definition: connected with language or the study of language

‍NUANCED.Definition: characterised by subtle shades of meaning or expression

‍BITE-SIZED.Definition: able to be consumed in small chunks

‍MOMENTUM.Definition: the force that keeps an object moving or keeps an event developing after it has started
